body.p: Data binding refers to the process of automatically populating or extracting data from a set of user interface elements. In Pivot, data binding is driven primarily by two methods of the Component class: load() and store(). Each method takes an instance of Dictionary<String, ?> called the "context". Calling load() causes data from the context to be "loaded" into the component; calling store() performs the reverse operation and "stores" data from the component into the context. Overloaded versions of both methods allow a caller to pass a JavaBean value as a bind context, which will be wrapped in a BeanDictionary and passed to the version that takes a dictionary argument. A third method, clear() allows a caller to reset any bindings.

The Container class overrides load() and store() to facilitate the use of nested contexts. When a container is assigned a context key, if a value with that key exists in the context passed to Container#load() or store(), that value becomes the context that is propagated to sub-components in further binds. This can significantly simplify the task of binding to complex data structures.

Note that not all components are bindable. In general, binding is limited to components that support user input. However, the read-only Label component is bindable, since it is often used to present non-editable data retrieved from a server (such as a database ID). Also, when a bindable component is disabled (effectively making it read only), its value is not stored during a store() operation.

The WTKX simply sets up the form structure and the bind keys:
body.source:
<Window title="Data Binding" maximized="true" xmlns:wtkx="http://pivot.apache.org/wtkx" xmlns="org.apache.pivot.wtk"> <content> <Border styles="{padding:6}"> <content> <BoxPane orientation="vertical" styles="{spacing:10, fill:true}"> <Form wtkx:id="form"> <sections> <Form.Section> <Label wtkx:id="sourceLabel" Form.label="Source" styles="{font:{italic:true}}"/>
<Label Form.label="ID" textKey="id"/> <TextInput Form.label="Name" textKey="name"/>
<BoxPane Form.label="Address" orientation="vertical" contextKey="address"> <TextInput textKey="street" prompt="Street"/> <BoxPane> <TextInput textKey="city" prompt="City"/> <TextInput textKey="state" textSize="6" prompt="State"/> <TextInput textKey="zip" textSize="10" prompt="Zip"/> </BoxPane> </BoxPane>
<TextInput Form.label="Phone" textKey="phoneNumber"/> <TextInput Form.label="Email" textKey="emailAddress"/>
<BoxPane Form.label="IM"> <TextInput textKey="imAccount.id"/> <ListButton selectedItemKey="imAccount.type" listData="['AIM', 'Jabber', 'Yahoo']"/> </BoxPane> </Form.Section> </sections> </Form>
<Separator/>
<BoxPane styles="{horizontalAlignment:'right'}"> <PushButton wtkx:id="loadJSONButton" buttonData="Load JSON"/> <PushButton wtkx:id="loadJavaButton" buttonData="Load Java"/> <PushButton wtkx:id="clearButton" buttonData="Clear"/> </BoxPane> </BoxPane> </content> </Border> </content> </Window>
body.p: Note that the <BoxPane> for the address section defines a context key. This creates a nested bind context for its sub-elements, allowing the sub-elements to refer to the bound values using a relative key (e.g. "street"). However, since the <BoxPane> for the IM account section does not define a context key, its sub-elements must refer to their bound values using a path that is relative to the root context (e.g. "imAccount.id").
